qas.question: In which document did the term "affirmative action" first appear?
Who was the author of the National Labor Relations Act?
Who did employers routinely blacklist of fire?
Who was able to review complaints about possible worker discrimination?
Which group of people did the Wagner Act fail to protect?
In which document did the term "non-affirmative action" first appear?
Who was the author of the National Non-Labor Relations Act?
Who wasn't able to review complaints about possible worker discrimination?
Which group of people did the Wagner Act protect?

context: The first appearance of the term 'affirmative action' was in the <a0_0><b5_0>National Labor Relations Act<b5_0/><a0_0/>, better known as the Wagner Act, of 1935.:15 Proposed and championed by <b6_0>U.S. <a1_0>Senator Robert F. Wagner<b6_0/><a1_0/> of New York, the Wagner Act was in line with President Roosevelt's goal of providing economic security to workers and other low-income groups. During this time period it was not uncommon for employers to blacklist or fire <a2_0><b7_0>employees associated with unions<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The Wagner Act allowed workers to unionize without fear of being discriminated against, and empowered a <a3_0><b8_0>National Labor Relations Board<b8_0/><a3_0/> to review potential cases of worker discrimination. In the event of discrimination, employees were to be restored to an appropriate status in the company through 'affirmative action'. While the Wagner Act protected workers and unions it did not protect <a4_0><b9_0>minorities<b9_0/><a4_0/>, who, exempting the Congress of Industrial Organizations, were often barred from union ranks.:11 This original coining of the term therefore has little to do with affirmative action policy as it is seen today, but helped set the stage for all policy meant to compensate or address an individual's unjust treatment.[citation needed]
